author: SamMonoRT
body:
When running the following CoreCLR tests on the Mono runtime from the dotnet\runtime repo, we get the error : 

```
System.ExecutionEngineException: Collectible AssemblyLoadContexts are not yet supported by MonoVM
             at System.Runtime.Loader.AssemblyLoadContext.InitializeAssemblyLoadContext(IntPtr thisHandlePtr, Boolean representsTPALoadContext, Boolean isCollectible) in /Users/samarthpatel/Documents/DotNetRunTime/runtime/src/mono/netcore/System.Private.CoreLib/src/System/Runtime/Loader/AssemblyLoadContext.Mono.cs:line 23
             at System.Runtime.Loader.AssemblyLoadContext..ctor(Boolean representsTPALoadContext, Boolean isCollectible, String name) in /Users/samarthpatel/Documents/DotNetRunTime/runtime/src/libraries/System.Private.CoreLib/src/System/Runtime/Loader/AssemblyLoadContext.cs:line 94
             at System.Runtime.Loader.AssemblyLoadContext..ctor(Boolean isCollectible) in 
```

Tests failing with this issue : 

1.	Interop/ICustomMarshaler/ConflictingNames/MultipleALCs/MultipleALCs.sh
2.	Loader/ContextualReflection/ContextualReflection/ContextualReflection.sh

Repro : Command to run individual tests : From the dotnet\runtime repo src\mono\netcore run this command - make run-tests-coreclr CoreClrTest="bash ../../artifacts/tests/coreclr/OSX.x64.Debug/Interop/ICustomMarshaler/ConflictingNames/MultipleALCs/MultipleALCs.sh"

nodes.author: CoffeeFlux
nodes.body: Using this as the new tracking issue for both the runtime and libraries tests.

nodes.author: SamMonoRT
nodes.body: This is not going to fit in for .NET6. Moving to 7.0.0 - Opportunistically might get to some cleanup work earlier.

nodes.author: srxqds
nodes.body: hope, you can keep the focus on it.

nodes.author: srxqds
nodes.body: Any progress and plan about it?

title: Collectible AssemblyLoadContexts are not supported by MonoVM

author: SamMonoRT
body:
Several failures seen when running the Loader/classloader/* tests. These are CoreCLR tests run on the mono runtime from the dotnet\runtime repo. It is quite possible, these may need to split in separate issues based on individual issues/missing implementations etc.

Repro :
See https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/6712f18b7ff3d6e582137c268cbb53c793f6536e/docs/workflow/testing/mono/testing.md, but the steps are approximately:
```
./build.sh mono+libs+clr.hosts -c Debug
pushd src/tests
./build.sh mono debug -test:Loader/classloader/regressions/asurt150271/test3.ilproj
popd
bash ./artifacts/tests/coreclr/OSX.x64.Debug/Loader/classloader/regressions/asurt150271/test3/test3.sh -coreroot=`pwd`/artifacts/tests/coreclr/OSX.x64.Debug/Tests/Core_Root 
```


The tests failing are : 
1. Loader/classloader/TypeInitialization/CctorsWithSideEffects/CctorThrowLDFTNStaticMethod/CctorThrowLDFTNStaticMethod.sh
5. Loader/classloader/regressions/asurt150271/test3/test3.sh
8. Loader/classloader/TSAmbiguities/SameMethodImpl/Override/HelloWorld/HelloWorld.sh
10. Loader/classloader/regressions/vsw529206/vsw529206ModuleCctor/vsw529206ModuleCctor.sh
12. Loader/classloader/rmv/il/RMV-2-15-12b/RMV-2-15-12b.sh
13. Loader/classloader/explicitlayout/Regressions/ASURT/ASURT150271/test3/test3.sh
15. Loader/classloader/generics/Instantiation/Negative/abstract01/abstract01.s
16. Loader/classloader/regressions/529206/vsw529206ModuleCctor/vsw529206ModuleCctor.sh
17. Loader/classloader/TypeInitialization/CoreCLR/CctorThrowStaticFieldBFI/CctorThrowStaticFieldBFI.sh
18. Loader/classloader/regressions/GitHub_11371/Negative_ByRefLikeType/Negative_ByRefLikeType.sh
19. Loader/classloader/TSAmbiguities/CollapsedInterfaces/HelloWorld/HelloWorld.sh
21. Loader/classloader/TypeInitialization/CctorsWithSideEffects/TypeLoadInitExcepBFI/TypeLoadInitExcepBFI.sh
23. Loader/classloader/TypeInitialization/CctorsWithSideEffects/CctorThrowStaticFieldBFI/CctorThrowStaticFieldBFI.sh
24. Loader/classloader/generics/regressions/dev10_531793/dev10_531793/dev10_531793.sh 
28. Loader/classloader/DefaultInterfaceMethods/reabstraction/reabstraction/reabstraction.sh

title: CoreCLR tests on Mono runtime : Failures in Loader/classloader/* tests

author: grendello
body:
Mono performs a lot of location probing when trying to find a shared library managed code tries to p/invoke into. This is not necessary on Android which won't have any DSOs in any of the locations probed by Mono.
There's also no pre-determined location where app shared libraries are, `Xamarin.Android` learns about the location(s) only when it's started - they are passed as application startup arguments (both filesystem locations
and APK locations). Mono should simply always call the `Xamarin.Android` `dlopen` hook, except when it sees that the p/invoke library name matches one of the following:

```
libandroid.so
libc.so
libdl.so
libEGL.so
libGLESv1_CM.so
libGLESv2.so
libGLESv3.so
libjnigraphics.so
liblog.so
libmediandk.so
libm.so
libOpenMAXAL.so
libOpenSLES.so
libstdc++.so
libz.so
```

The list is taken from the Android NDK, by listing any of the `platforms/android-API_LEVEL/arch-*/usr/lib` directories and it names the only "blessed" shared libraries that are accessible to the application in `/system`.
At the same time, Mono should not `stat` the files in `/system` if it sees any of the above names, but simply issue a `dlopen` + `dlsym` for the specified name.

/cc @CoffeeFlux

title: [Android] Mono should not probe any filesystem locations for shared libraries

author: lambdageek
body:
When Mono loads an assembly, we do a version check following the .NET Core rules - if an assembly has a version that is newer than what is requested, loading succeeds.  If the assembly has an older version and a newer version is requested, the load fails.

However if the assembly was previously loaded, we ignore the version when trying to load it again.

```csharp
                 // succeeds - sug.dll is version 1.0.0.0
		var t = Type.GetType ("sug.Class1, sug, Version=0.0.0.0, Culture=Neutral", throwOnError: true);
		Console.WriteLine ($"{t.AssemblyQualifiedName}");
                 // should fail, but succeeds because we already loaded sug.dll
		var t2 = Type.GetType ("sug.Class1, sug, Version=42.0.0.0, Culture=Neutral", throwOnError: true);
		Console.WriteLine ($"{t2.AssemblyQualifiedName}");
```

---

Reproduction:

Download and unzip the attached file 
[loadTwice.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/files/4827347/loadTwice.zip)


```console
$ cd loadTwice/aug
$ dotnet build
$ dotnet run
```

Expected output:
```console
sug.Class1, sug, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null
Unhandled exception. System.IO.FileLoadException: Could not load file or assembly 'sug, Version=255.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null'. The located assembly's manifest definition does not match the assembly reference. (0x80131040)
File name: 'sug, Version=255.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null'
   at System.RuntimeTypeHandle.GetTypeByName(String name, Boolean throwOnError, Boolean ignoreCase, StackCrawlMarkHandle stackMark, ObjectHandleOnStack assemblyLoadContext, Boolean loadTypeFromPartialName, ObjectHandleOnStack type, ObjectHandleOnStack keepalive)
   at System.RuntimeTypeHandle.GetTypeByName(String name, Boolean throwOnError, Boolean ignoreCase, StackCrawlMark& stackMark, AssemblyLoadContext assemblyLoadContext, Boolean loadTypeFromPartialName)
   at System.RuntimeType.GetType(String typeName, Boolean throwOnError, Boolean ignoreCase, StackCrawlMark& stackMark)
   at System.Type.GetType(String typeName, Boolean throwOnError)
   at aug.Program.Main(String[] args) in /private/tmp/loadTwice/aug/Program.cs:line 11
```

Actual output:
```console
sug.Class1, sug, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35
sug.Class1, sug, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35
```

This is related to https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/31954/commits/81fd7eb7afb8aed08b544b28126cd0ca7345f78a
That test should be re-enabled for Mono when this issue is fixed.

title: [Mono] Loader should check requested version if assembly is already loaded

author: CoffeeFlux
body:
Mono currently has a native parser and two managed parsers (`TypeNameParser` and `TypeSpec`) for... reasons. Ideally we would only have a single managed implementation, use it as much as possible, and share it with CoreCLR.

Ideally, Mono should share the same assembly name parsing logic as CoreCLR, which is `AssemblyNameParser.TryParse`.

We can probably share for most uses in reflection. The Mono runtime also calls this internally from some places, and also I think the AOT compiler might need it. One idea is to compile the managed `TypeNameParser` as a library using NativeAOT and call it from the AOT compiler.

nodes.author: teo-tsirpanis
nodes.body:
I'd be interested in working at this and have removed `TypeSpec` in a branch of mine. The native type name parser can be removed by replacing it with the runtime calling the managed one, just like how CoreCLR does it.

However, the native type name parser is [depended upon by the embedding API](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/eb99e9380129ff621132e6c60113793804713860/src/native/public/mono/metadata/details/reflection-functions.h#L9C46-L9C72), and reimplementing `mono_reflection_parse_type` on top of the managed parser does not seem easy. Let me know how to proceed.

nodes.author: jkotas
nodes.body:
> the native type name parser is [depended upon by the embedding API](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/eb99e9380129ff621132e6c60113793804713860/src/native/public/mono/metadata/details/reflection-functions.h#L9C46-L9C72), and reimplementing mono_reflection_parse_type on top of the managed parser does not seem easy

Yes, that sounds non-trival. I would leave it alone.

title: Finalizer_CollectibleWithNoAssemblyLoaded timing out

author: lambdageek
body:
Running the following program with Mono will crash

```csharp
using System;
using System.Threading;
using System.Reflection;

namespace X
{
    class Program
    {
        static void Main(string[] args)
        {

	    Thread.CurrentThread.Name = "Main-Thread";
	    
	    AppDomain.CurrentDomain.AssemblyLoad += (_sender, evt) => {
		var assm = evt.LoadedAssembly;
		var name = assm.GetName();
		// removing this line fixes the crash
#if true
		Console.WriteLine ($" : Loaded {name.Name} from '{assm.Location}' on {Thread.CurrentThread.Name}");
#endif
	    };
	    
	    var allDone = new ManualResetEventSlim ();
	    var proceed = new ManualResetEventSlim ();

	    var conflictThread = new Thread(() => {
		proceed.Set();
		Console.WriteLine ($" - {Thread.CurrentThread.Name} waiting for all done");
		allDone.Wait();
	    });
	    conflictThread.Name = "Conflict-Thread";
	    conflictThread.Start();

	    proceed.Wait ();
	    allDone.Set ();
	    Thread.Sleep (1000);
	    Console.WriteLine ($" {Thread.CurrentThread.Name} exiting");
        }
    }
}
```

See info in [area-owners.md](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/area-owners.md) if you want to be subscribed.
<details>
<summary>Issue Details</summary>
<hr />


Running the following program with Mono will crash

```csharp
using System;
using System.Threading;
using System.Reflection;

namespace X
{
    class Program
    {
        static void Main(string[] args)
        {

	    Thread.CurrentThread.Name = "Main-Thread";
	    
	    AppDomain.CurrentDomain.AssemblyLoad += (_sender, evt) => {
		var assm = evt.LoadedAssembly;
		var name = assm.GetName();
		// removing this line fixes the crash
#if true
		Console.WriteLine ($" : Loaded {name.Name} from '{assm.Location}' on {Thread.CurrentThread.Name}");
#endif
	    };
	    
	    var allDone = new ManualResetEventSlim ();
	    var proceed = new ManualResetEventSlim ();

	    var conflictThread = new Thread(() => {
		proceed.Set();
		Console.WriteLine ($" - {Thread.CurrentThread.Name} waiting for all done");
		allDone.Wait();
	    });
	    conflictThread.Name = "Conflict-Thread";
	    conflictThread.Start();

	    proceed.Wait ();
	    allDone.Set ();
	    Thread.Sleep (1000);
	    Console.WriteLine ($" {Thread.CurrentThread.Name} exiting");
        }
    }
}
```

Expected Output: no crash

author: uweigand
body:
### Description

While attempting to run the host.tests --test suite under the Mono runtime, I'm seeing failures in two of the HostActivation test cases that seem to be caused by a difference in behavior between the Mono loader and the CoreCLR loader.

In particular, the Mono loader will always scan for an assembly in the application base directory (i.e. the value of the managed `AppContext.BaseDirectory`), and load the assembly from there if present (and the version matches), even if it wasn't listed in the deps.json file.   The CoreCLR loader will instead fail the load.

### Reproduction Steps

Build runtime on linux-s390x and run `./build host.tests --test`, specifically the HostActivation tests.

(Note: this is not currently reproducible in unpatched mainline due to other issues preventing the host.tests from even starting.)

### Expected behavior

Tests pass.

### Actual behavior

The following test cases fail:

```
Microsoft.DotNet.CoreSetup.Test.HostActivation.LightupAppActivation.Muxer_activation_of_LightupApp_WithLightupLib_and_Roll_Backwards_Fails
Microsoft.DotNet.CoreSetup.Test.HostActivation.LightupAppActivation.Muxer_activation_of_LightupApp_WithLightupLib_NoLightupDepsJson_Fails
```

Investigating the Roll_Backward_Fails failures in more detail, the test fails with:
```
Expected command to fail but it did not.
```
Specifically, the test expects to fail because the `LightupLib.dll` assembly should not be found, because it is not listed in a deps.json file with the correct version number.  And with the CoreCLR loader, this is what happens.   But with the Mono loader, we see the load succeed.

Using a `MONO_LOG_LEVEL=debug MONO_LOG_MASK=asm` trace shows:
```
Mono: Request to load LightupLib in alc 0x2aa3a04b650
Mono: netcore preload hook: did not find 'LightupLib'.
Mono: ApplicationBase is /home/uweigand/runtime/artifacts/tests/Debug/ha/lbwn5dgb.jmm/LightupClient/bin/
Mono: Assembly Loader probing location: '/home/uweigand/runtime/artifacts/tests/Debug/ha/lbwn5dgb.jmm/LightupClient/bin/LightupLib.dll'.
Mono: Image addref LightupLib[0x2aa3a22e0c0] (default ALC) -> /home/uweigand/runtime/artifacts/tests/Debug/ha/lbwn5dgb.jmm/LightupClient/bin/LightupLib.dll[0x2aa3a2421a0]: 2
Mono: Predicate: wanted = LightupLib, Version=0.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null
Mono: Predicate: candidate = LightupLib, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null
Mono: Predicate: candidate and wanted names match, returning TRUE
Mono: Prepared to set up assembly 'LightupLib' (/home/uweigand/runtime/artifacts/tests/Debug/ha/lbwn5dgb.jmm/LightupClient/bin/LightupLib.dll)
Mono: Loading assembly LightupLib (0x2aa3a22e0c0) into domain LightupClient.dll (0x2aa3a04b5f0) and ALC 0x2aa3a04b650
Mono: Assembly LightupLib[0x2aa3a22e0c0] added to ALC 'Default'[0x2aa3a04b650], ref_count=1
Mono: Assembly Loader loaded assembly from location: '/home/uweigand/runtime/artifacts/tests/Debug/ha/lbwn5dgb.jmm/LightupClient/bin/LightupLib.dll'.
Mono: Assembly found with the filesystem probing logic: 'LightupLib'.
```
so the file was found via the ApplicationBase logic.

Looking at the CoreCLR loader, I cannot find any equivalent logic, so I'm not really sure what the intended behavior is.  Experimentally, the test case completes successfully (and I don't see regressions in the other tests) if I simply disable the ApplicationBase logic in the Mono loader completely.


### Regression?

No

### Known Workarounds

_No response_

### Configuration

Current mainline built on linux-s390x using the Mono runtime.

### Other information

This is likely also related to a side discussion in https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/60550
CC @lambdageek

nodes.author: lambdageek
nodes.body: Hmm.  We added this in https://github.com/mono/mono/pull/18270 apparently.  Not clear if it was solving some issue that we later solved in a better way or if it was compensating for a lack of the dotnet host.  In any case it should be safe to remove it if the desktop hosting tests pass - mobile & wasm wouldn't depend on this relatively new behavior, I think.

nodes.author: lambdageek
nodes.body:
Interesting. I think this was probably added to deal with xunit.  Doing the obvious "fix" to drop the ApplicationBase probing immediately breaks libraries tests in dotnet/runtime.

We might need to fix this by working around also including a provision for xunit.console like in https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/60987

nodes.author: lambdageek
nodes.body:
I'm very confused.  It seems like the `ApplicationBase` probing is necessary for the `System.Runtime.Extensions.Tests` tests to work, but I can't find anything in CoreCLR that lookat at that property - so I'm unclear on how the test passes there. 

Mono failure log: https://gist.github.com/lambdageek/72c5b8cfd4d4ddb501c3661312910047

@vitek-karas @VSadov what am I missing: does CoreCLR look for assemblies in `APP_CONTEXT_BASE_DIRECTORY` ever  (in non-single file configurations --- in this case it's just a src/libraries test using the test host, I think)? 

For a test like `AppDomainTests.TypeResolve` https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/f7be57f11b7e0a4782f3836669ec1bebcd53ccd8/src/libraries/System.Runtime.Extensions/tests/System/AppDomainTests.cs#L704  I think we rely on the StackCrawlMark in both CoreCLR and Mono to get the calling assembly and the use that as part of the load algorithm (coreclr: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/src/coreclr/vm/assemblynative.cpp#L35), right? I suppose it's possible Mono is either incorrectly discovering the caller assembly, or it gets dropped somewhere along the way in the loader.  I plan to investigate this direction next - but I want to make sure it's definitely the case that the application base directory is not relevant for CoreCLR.

nodes.author: vitek-karas
nodes.body: It should not look there on its own. That said, the value of AppContext.BaseDirectory is frequently used to resolve missing assemblies at runtime (via one of the various loader hooks/events). Not sure if the test does this.

nodes.author: uweigand
nodes.body:
@lambdageek I can reproduce three failing tests in `System.Runtime.Extensions.Tests`.   Interestingly, I find an entry for `TestApp.exe` in the `TRUSTED_PLATFORM_ASSEMBLIES` passed by the host to Mono, so I would have thought it should be found via that.

I suspect the problem is simply related to the `.exe` extension.   Looking into `mono_core_preload_hook` I see:

```
        basename = g_strconcat (aname->name, ".dll", (const char*)NULL); /* TODO: make sure CoreCLR never needs to load .exe files */
```

which appears to be an incorrect assumption in this case.

title: [mono] Enable DispatchProxyTests.DispatchProxyTests.Test_Unloadability

author: lambdageek
body:
The global loader lock has two high-level problems:

1. It inhibits concurrency
2. We sometimes hold it while calling managed code (class cctors, assembly load callbacks) which can lead to deadlocks.


We should continue to look for opportunities to move code out of the global loader lock into specific locks for individual data structures.

Some ideas / Tracking:

- [ ] Implement "class readiness levels" https://github.com/mono/mono/issues/7856
- [ ] Implement "please retry" mode for class initialization (comment: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/51864#issuecomment-953977929)

author: lateralusX
body:
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/77399 setup basic support for unloadable ALCs in Mono. This issue tracks remaining work to complete unloadable ALCs on Mono runtime. Initial list of work items is extracted from https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/design/mono/unloadability.md#remaining-work:

## Must
- [ ] **Enable** Unloading is currently disabled due to CI failures
- [ ]  **Managed frames.** Frames belonging to code in the ALC should keep the ALC alive. This can be implemented by having all methods allocate a volatile local variable and store a reference to their LoaderAllocator object into it.
- [ ] **Reflection pointers.** Icalls which take a assembly/type etc. handle as parameter need to keep the ALC alive, otherwise there will be subtle races.
- [ ] **TLS variables.**
- [ ] **Testing and leak detection.**
- [ ] **Enable/disable compiler flag.**

## Should
- [ ] **Profiling, perf counters.**
- [ ] **Diagnostics support.** What keeps an ALC alive.

## Could
- [ ] **Boehm GC support.**

Frames belonging to code in the ALC should keep the ALC alive. This can be implemented by having all methods allocate a volatile local variable and store a reference to their LoaderAllocator object into it. - [ ] Reflection pointers. Icalls which take a assembly/type etc. handle as parameter need to keep the ALC alive, otherwise there will be subtle races. - [ ] TLS variables. - [ ] Testing and leak detection. - [ ] Enable/disable compiler flag. ##Should - [ ] Thread abort. Although its not part of current .NET APIs, it might be useful to have a way to abort threads executing code in an ALC, similarly to how domain unloads worked previously. - [ ] Profiling, perf counters, etc. - [ ] Diagnostics support, i.e. what keeps an ALC alive. ##Could - [ ] Boehm GC support.

nodes.author: teo-tsirpanis
nodes.body:
> abort threads executing code in an ALC, similarly to how domain unloads worked previously.

Note that forceful unloading of ALCs is [an explicit non-goal](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/design/features/unloadability.md#non-goals) and generally frowned upon for the same reason `Thread.Abort` is bad. Are you sure you want it?

nodes.author: teo-tsirpanis
nodes.body: @steveisok what is the milestone for this? `untriaged` means without a milestone and gets automatically removed by the bot.

nodes.author: lateralusX
nodes.body:
> > abort threads executing code in an ALC, similarly to how domain unloads worked previously.
> 
> Note that forceful unloading of ALCs is [an explicit non-goal](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/design/features/unloadability.md#non-goals) and generally frowned upon for the same reason `Thread.Abort` is bad. Are you sure you want it?

Fully aware on existing unload design and Thread.Abort impact and it has been discussed over last years in various forms. This issue might not be the right form to carry additional/new "ideas" and it's generally not something we would just implement, but since we have many customers that tries to mitigate the lack of app domains (Unity is one example) we also work on ideas going forward on how to simplify/assist developers with existing scenarios/solutions relying on aspects of app domains to move over to dotnet runtime. I removed the Thread.Abort from this issue since it falls into a wider discussion and not directly needed for Mono ALC support.

nodes.author: CeSun
nodes.body:
In the future, Mono will definitely be replaced by CoreCLR. Mono faces the risk of ceasing updates. The Alc uninstallation issue can only address the most pressing concerns. If Mono ceases updates in the future, everyone will have to migrate to CoreCLR or NativeAOT.
﻿
However, the current embedded API of CoreCLR seems to be designed solely for desktop applications. Therefore, I hope that the .NET team will consider improving the embedded solution so that third-party hosts can easily embed the .NET runtime.

I have a proposal and hope to get your support!：

nodes.author: gktval
nodes.body:
I am also also seeing this with local resx files. If I step through the code during debugging, then it works. But without BreakPoints, it crashes with System.Io.FilenotFoundException. This just started on 7.0.86 on Android for me. 

I have the resource files Build Action set as Embedded resource.

Did you find a workaround?

nodes.author: davibittencourtome
nodes.body: I am also suffering this problem. Any news on how to resolve?

nodes.author: melixor
nodes.body: I'm fighting with the same problem since this morning after my project worked always fine.

nodes.author: XamlTest
nodes.body:
Verified this on Visual Studio Enterprise 17.7.0 Preview 2.0. Repro on Android 13.0-API33 and iOS 16.4, not repro on Windows 11 with below Project:
[MauiApp1.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/maui/files/11935264/MauiApp1.zip)

nodes.author: CobaltGoldCS
nodes.body: This issue is preventing me from using several external libraries that provide localization. Has anyone found any workarounds _without_ using a debugger and breakpoints?

nodes.author: Kebechet
nodes.body:
I also experience the same issue. But it showed up just lately. In some past versions it worked correctly.

Workaround:
- for this to work I had to disable 4 exceptions from `Common Language Runtime Exceptions`:
  - `System.Exception`
  - `System.IO.FileNotFoundException`
  - `System.IO.IOException`
  - `System.SystemException`

nodes.author: ianvink
nodes.body:
This has started to happen as of the latest Visual Studio Version 17.7.5

Workaround as @Kebechet said, disable exceptions in the Exceptions Settings tab. Then it works

nodes.author: FrankVDL2471
nodes.body:
Any fix / workaround on this ?
I'm having the same issue and disabling the exceptions does not work for me.

nodes.body:

nodes.author: jonathanpeppers
nodes.body: Sorry, I see the repro: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/103994

nodes.author: jonathanpeppers
nodes.body:
The stacktrace is inside:
```
System.IO.FileNotFoundException
   at System.Reflection.Assembly.Load(AssemblyName assemblyRef, StackCrawlMark& stackMark, AssemblyLoadContext assemblyLoadContext)
   at System.Reflection.RuntimeAssembly.InternalGetSatelliteAssembly(Assembly assembly, CultureInfo culture, Version version, Boolean throwOnFileNotFound)
```
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/c5e8f83db1606a89e70a9f4a0ac2fc03dea2418c/src/mono/System.Private.CoreLib/src/System/Reflection/RuntimeAssembly.cs#L433

But then everything works, it seems like the exception is caught and moves on.

I think we just move this to dotnet/runtime, it's not a dotnet/maui issue.
